author: By Nicholas Bakalar
title: Gum Disease Tied to Colon Cancer Risk
description: People with periodontal disease had a higher risk of polyps that can lead to colon cancer.
content: Gum disease may increase your risk of colorectal cancer.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What Kamala Harris Means for Wall Street and Silicon Valley
description: Joe Biden’s selection of a relatively moderate vice-presidential running mate seems to have been well received among the executive class.
content: Want this delivered to your inbox each day? Sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Amazon Is So Much Bricks and Mortar
description: E-commerce is not a purely online activity. It affects our real world, too, in both constructive and potentially harmful ways.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Remote Control: Making Television Mid-Pandemic
description: When TV production stopped in the spring, a few showrunners began working on pandemic-themed series that could be shot mostly from afar. But will viewers even want more shut-in stories?
content: On a sun-dazzled morning in early July, the actor Leslie Odom Jr. readied himself for another take. At a marble-topped table in a Los Angeles bungalow, he pecked at a laptop, waiting for the actress playing his wife to enter. This was midway through a three-day shoot for “Love in the Time of Corona,” a Freeform limited series that premieres on Aug. 22.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Chamberlin
title: Infertility Was Distressing. The Military Made It Even More Complicated.
description: For service members like me, Tricare health insurance and the limited number of military medical facilities offering fertility treatments add more stress to an already emotional process.
content: The period of my life when I assumed pregnancy could be planned ended only two years ago — but it feels like a distant memory. It’s almost laughable, considering the years I spent worrying about accidental pregnancies. Once I was ready, I thought I would be in control of when and how it would happen. My husband, Mike, and I were both on active duty in the Army, with access to free medical care and paid parental leave. We had served together in two overseas duty stations and planned to start our family when we returned to the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Greer and Deb Amlen
title: Poem: The Unsolvable Puzzle
description: Who can explain feelings or passions, much less the labyrinthine road one travels to make sense of them? Michael Greer’s use of puzzle vocabulary will be familiar to solvers, but are you ready for the twist at the end?
content: Who can explain feelings or passions, much less the labyrinthine road one travels to make sense of them? Michael Greer’s use of puzzle vocabulary will be familiar to solvers, but are you ready for the twist at the end?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Some Conferences Postponed Football. Not So Fast in the South.
description: The Big Ten and Pac-12 conferences have said they won’t play in the fall. The Southeastern, Atlantic Coast and Big 12 conferences are biding for time.
content: ATLANTA — The Big Ten and the Pac-12 called off their football seasons before they started. The South’s premier college football conferences called a play for time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Courtney Rubin
title: The Race Is On to Be the Peloton of Weight Lifting
description: Three companies — Tempo, Tonal and Forme Life — are competing to supplant cheap dumbbells with smart machines priced in the four figures.
content: Since last year, Amay Sheth, a 26-year-old start-up founder in Greenwich Village, Manhattan, has been scheming to shave time off his visits to his parents in Westchester County — and going less often. The reason: He can’t wait to get home to his Tonal, a $2,995 smart strength-training device that packs a weight room’s worth of equipment in one machine that’s the size of a poster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Iman Stevenson
title: He’s Sharing the History of Black New York, One Tweet at a Time
description: Meet the grad student with a killer wardrobe who digs in the archives and takes the gems to Twitter.
content: When a video of a racist attack on Black children by white residents of Rosedale, Queens, in 1975 was posted on Twitter last summer, it quickly drew attention — and has now been viewed over 4.5 million times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: Kamala Harris as V.P. Pick Could Mean More Maya Rudolph on ‘S.N.L.’
description: The actress has not committed to continuing her Emmy-nominated depiction of the vice-presidential nominee, but she seemed intrigued.
content: As a nation unpacks the political ripples of Kamala Harris’s selection on Tuesday as the Democratic vice-presidential nominee, at least one sizable constituency could stand to benefit: those who enjoyed Maya Rudolph’s star appearances as the California senator on “Saturday Night Live.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Asher Elbein
title: Making Sense of ‘One of the Most Baffling Animals That Ever Lived’
description: Important mysteries have been solved about a reptile with a giraffe-like neck that hunted prey 242 million years ago.
content: Nearly 250 million years ago, a very odd reptile patrolled the shorelines and coves of the Triassic Alps. Called Tanystropheus, it had a toothy head and a body echoing that of modern monitor lizards. But between them stretched a horizontal, giraffe-like neck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Hong Kong, Gun Crime in Britain, WeChat: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Curtis Rush
title: Lightning’s Five OT Win Tested Legs, Hearts and Stomachs
description: Game 1 of the first-round series between Tampa Bay and Columbus was the fourth-longest game in N.H.L. history.
content: TORONTO — The puck dropped at 3 p.m. Eastern time and the playoff game between the Tampa Bay Lightning and Columbus Blue Jackets went on for more than six hours, finally coming to an end at 9:22 p.m., with Tampa Bay winning, 3-2, in the fifth overtime period.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins
title: Trump’s Cabinet From Hell
description: The contest is over. Meet the winning Worst.
content: If you run into Attorney General William Barr over the weekend, be sure to congratulate him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Kandell
title: Sumner Redstone Dies at 97; Built Media Empire and Long Reigned Over It
description: Starting with a chain of drive-in movie theaters, Mr. Redstone negotiated, sued and otherwise fought to amass a domain that included CBS and Viacom.
content: Sumner M. Redstone, the billionaire entrepreneur who saw business as combat and his advancing years as no obstacle in building a media empire that encompassed CBS and Viacom, died on Tuesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 97.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gretchen Reynolds
title: Whether You Are a Night Owl or Early Bird May Affect How Much You Move
description: Early risers did the equivalent of walking 20 to 30 minutes more each day compared to “evening types,” who tend to stay up late.
content: People who are evening types go to bed later and wake up later than morning types. They also tend to move around far less throughout the day, according to an interesting new study of how our innate body clocks may be linked to our physical activity habits. The study, one of the first to objectively track daily movements of a large sample of early birds and night owls, suggests that knowing our chronotype might be important for our health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Levy and Lauren Kilgour
title: Don’t Make College Kids the Coronavirus Police
description: Many universities are asking students to wear masks and avoid parties — and to report on peers who break the rules. It could backfire.
content: Hundreds of American colleges and universities have opted to begin the fall semester at least partly in person, allowing some or all of their students onto campus to live and study. These schools are going to great lengths to impress upon students that their behavior determines whether campuses can stay open or whether they will have to head back to their parents’ homes by October. In many cases, schools are requiring students to sign “social contracts” in which they promise not to party, have overnight dorm guests, walk across campus without masks or otherwise conduct themselves as college students normally do — and often attaching strict penalties if students violate the rules.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: It’s James Harden Appreciation Day
description: In this week’s newsletter, Marc Stein selects the N.B.A.’s All-Lefty Team and wonders what could have been for Zion Williamson’s too-short rookie season.
content: Want more basketball in your inbox? Sign up for Marc Stein’s weekly N.B.A. newsletter here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: ‘Fat Talks,’ an Investigation, and a Reckoning: How Collegiate Runners Forced Reform
description: Athletes detailed “fat talks” and eating disorders they said a prominent coach at Wesleyan had fostered. When the same coach was assigned to lead changes in the environment he created, the students protested once again.
content: In early March, 36 Wesleyan University track and cross-country alumni signed a letter describing a culture of rampant body shaming and eating disorders within the program that they said a prominent coach had fostered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: New Jersey Gives Schools an All-Remote Option
description: The decision comes as the teachers union, a close ally of Gov. Philip D. Murphy, had publicly raised concerns about the safety of holding in-person classes.
content: Gov. Philip D. Murphy is giving New Jersey districts the option to offer all-virtual classes when school resumes next month, relaxing his original requirement that teachers provide some in-person classroom instruction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: New York City Could Use a Champion. Who Will Step Up?
description: New York seems to be missing the kind of civic leadership that helped the city recover from previous financial and psychic crises.
content: Waves of death and joblessness, hunger and economic depression — all at a scale rarely rivaled in New York City history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alina Tugend
title: Feel Like You’re Going Out of Your Mind? Consider Your Mind-Set
description: No one likes to make mistakes, but how you manage them can be a key to a stronger future.
content: This article is part of a series on resilience in troubled times — what we can learn about it from history and personal experiences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik and Jake Malooley
title: Second City Is Trying Not to Be Racist. Will It Work This Time?
description: For more than 60 years, the premier home for improv comedy was a bastion of whiteness where performers of color were consistently demeaned. Now it is trying to remake itself entirely.
content: What happens when a comedy institution realizes that a punchline is not worth a performer’s pain?
source.name: The New York Times

title: U.S. Coronavirus Death Toll Reflects Sun Belt Outbreaks
description: With the exception of three anomalous days this summer, Wednesday’s U.S. total of more than 1,470 deaths was the highest since late May. Experts say the nation’s new coronavirus database creates problems for hospitals.
content: Officials across the United States reported more than 1,470 deaths on Wednesday, the highest single-day total yet in August, according to a New York Times database, and a reflection of the continued toll of the early-summer case surge in Sun Belt states.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: For Belarus Leader, a Fading Aura of Invincibility
description: Undermined by the pandemic and a deepening economic crisis, and surrounded by sycophants, Aleksandr Lukashenko badly miscalculated in the recent election.
content: MOSCOW — The autocratic leader of Belarus, never a stickler for accurate vote counting, boasted early in his 26-year rule that he was so popular that he had to falsify his share of the vote because the original number — 93.5 percent — was too implausibly high. He said he made it 86 percent instead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher, Adam Nagourney and Jennifer Medina
title: Geographic balance takes a back seat to gender and race.
description: Gender and race have now surpassed geographic balance when it comes to building a ticket for the White House.
content: Gender and race have now surpassed geographic balance when it comes to building a ticket for the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Can Neil Young Block Trump From Using His Songs? It’s Complicated
description: Musicians have complained about politicians playing their music at events for years. Now, with Mr. Young suing for copyright infringement, they are trying a new strategy.
content: On Election Day in 2018, Neil Young posted a frustrated statement about President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Lasky
title: $950,000 Homes in New York, Utah and Pennsylvania
description: An 1830s farmhouse in Cornwallville, a 19th-century house with a 1970s addition near Salt Lake City and a 1925 stone house in Haverford.
content: Known as Do-Nothing Farm, this property is in Greene County, nine miles northeast (downhill) of the Catskills ski town of Windham and 125 miles north of New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: The Daily News Is Now a Newspaper Without a Newsroom
description: Tribune Publishing said that it was permanently closing the tabloid’s office in Lower Manhattan. As its journalists work remotely during the pandemic, plans for a future workplace are uncertain.
content: A tabloid once famous for its bustling, big-city newsroom no longer has a newsroom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson and Michael Forsythe
title: Luxury Homes Tie Chinese Communist Elite to Hong Kong’s Fate
description: Three top leaders of China’s Communist Party have relatives who own assets in Hong Kong, including more than $51 million in luxury real estate, a New York Times investigation shows.
content: HONG KONG — Li Qianxin, the elder daughter of the Chinese Communist Party’s No. 3 leader, has quietly crafted a life in Hong Kong that traverses the city’s financial elite and the secretive world of Chinese politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Flegenheimer and Lisa Lerer
title: Kamala Harris, a Political Fighter Shaped by Life in Two Worlds
description: She grew up around Berkeley activists but came to believe working from inside the system had greater power to effect change.
content: Kamala Harris’s first act as a political candidate was knocking out a former boxer: the progressive San Francisco district attorney who had been her boss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Elizabeth Lewis
title: For Black Suffragists, the Lens Was a Mighty Sword
description: Photographs of generations of Black suffragists offer invaluable documents about their thwarted and central roles in the history of women’s rights.
content: On the last day of his life, Frederick Douglass attended a meeting of the National Women’s Council. The prodigious orator and abolitionist came home to Cedar Hill, his hilltop house in the Anacostia neighborhood of Washington, D.C.; spoke with his wife at the time, Helen Pitts Douglass, about the events and future plans; clasped his hands to his chest and died that evening. It seemed impossible that such an indomitable man was gone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Why Your Brain Short-Circuits When a Kid Cries
description: Their wailing has evolved to be maximally distracting.
content: A few weeks ago, I was deeply immersed in an article I was editing when I heard a high-pitched wail from downstairs. The acoustics of my parents’ house are so porous that even when my children have meltdowns from a distance away, they sound like they are happening in my face. So I could hear that my 4-year-old was sobbing because she decided she could not tolerate the sound of the washing machine, a noise that had never, ever bothered her before. Three other sentient adults — my parents and my husband — attended to my daughter’s hulking out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debora L. Spar
title: The Poly-Parent Households Are Coming
description: We’re on the cusp of a technological revolution in baby making. What it means to be a family could be next.
content: Consider the following scenario: Anna and Nicole, 36 and 39 years old, have been close friends since college. They each dated various men throughout their 20s and 30s, and had a smattering of romantic relationships that didn’t quite work out. But now, as they approach midlife, both women have grown weary of the merry-go-round of online dating and of searching for men who might — or might not — make appropriate fathers for the babies they don’t yet have. Both Anna and Nicole want children. They want to raise those children in a stable, nurturing environment, and to continue the legacy of their own parents and grandparents. And so they decide to have a baby — a baby that is genetically their own — together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Robert Ryland, Who Broke a Tennis Barrier, Dies at 100
description: The first professional Black player, he also taught future tennis stars, as well as a few stars of show business.
content: Robert Ryland, the first Black professional tennis player and for many years a well-regarded coach of younger players and celebrities, died on Aug. 2 at his stepson’s home in Provincetown, Mass. He was 100.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: 1,193 Quarantined for Covid. Is This a Successful School Reopening?
description: A suburban Atlanta county opened its schools amid controversy and a growing case count, previewing a difficult national back-to-school season.
content: CANTON, Ga. — The first letter went out on Aug. 4, one day after students in the Cherokee County School District returned to their classrooms for the first time since the eruption of the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Becky Lebowitz Hanger, Henry Fountain and Lisa Friedman
title: The Story Behind Our Story: Extreme Heat and Inequity
description: Also this week, art and science come together in the Alps and a vice-presidential pick
content: Welcome to the Climate Fwd: newsletter. The New York Times climate team emails readers once a week with stories and insights about climate change. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Foster Kamer
title: The Great Gotham Vroom Boom of 2020
description: New Yorkers have historically been lukewarm on car ownership. Then came the you-know-what.
content: There’s a special place in hell for the authors of those trend stories that concern New Yorkers discovering things for the first time as though they are new.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag and Patrick McGeehan
title: Retail chains are abandoning Manhattan.
description: In the heart of Manhattan, national chains including J.C. Penney, Kate Spade, Subway and Le Pain Quotidien have shuttered branches for good. Many other large brands, like Victoria’s Secret and the Gap, have kept their high-profile locations closed in Manhattan, while reopening in other states.
content: In the heart of Manhattan, national chains including J.C. Penney, Kate Spade, Subway and Le Pain Quotidien have shuttered branches for good. Many other large brands, like Victoria’s Secret and the Gap, have kept their high-profile locations closed in Manhattan, while reopening in other states.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: Bankrupt Brooks Brothers Finds a Buyer
description: The retailer is seeking court approval of a $325 million sale to a group backed by the mall owner Simon Property Group and Authentic Brands Group, a licensing firm.
content: Brooks Brothers, the venerable retailer that was founded in 1818 and filed for bankruptcy last month, said it would be sold to Simon Property Group, the biggest mall operator in the United States, and Authentic Brands Group, a licensing firm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edmund Lee
title: Sumner Redstone, Hollywood Brawler
description: He embodied the impolite era of the media mogul, a time before streaming, when movie theaters and cable TV were all the rage.
content: Sumner M. Redstone belonged to the Age of the Media Mogul, a time before Apple, Facebook, Amazon and Google, when street-smart executives like Rupert Murdoch, Barry Diller and John Malone brawled in a bid to dominate the world’s screen time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff
title: Mexico’s Former President Accused in Bribery Scandal
description: Corruption allegations against past presidents have never led to prosecution. Will the latest claims about Enrique Peña Nieto lead to the first?
content: MEXICO CITY — For Mexicans, the news is disturbing — and disturbingly familiar. A key witness in a major corruption case has accused former President Enrique Peña Nieto of directing bribes to fund his presidential campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Bradley
title: How American Guns Are Fueling U.K. Crime
description: Handguns are quietly being smuggled into Britain, despite tough gun-control laws. The police fear that the illegal weapons are contributing to a rise in gang-related crime.
content: NORTHAMPTON, England — Josh Bains was 28 when he was killed after an argument over a drug debt of about $50 just a few miles from the English village where he grew up — with a gun that had traveled thousands of miles from America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: 60 Talented Educators Join The New York Times Teaching Project
description: Representing 29 states and subject areas across the curriculum, these teachers will bring the mission of The Times to their schools for the 2020-21 school year.
content: In July, we officially welcomed a distinguished group of 60 educators to The New York Times Teaching Project. Chosen from hundreds of applicants and representing 29 states, these teachers are passionate about bringing the mission of The Times — helping people understand the world through on-the-ground, expert and deeply reported independent journalism — to their school communities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu
title: Postponed College Football Games Could Disrupt $1 Billion in TV Ads
description: Fox and Disney, which owns ESPN and ABC, prepare to take another hit from a pandemic that has already affected them with shutdowns and delays.
content: The postponement of much of the college football season could disrupt the flow of more than $1 billion from advertisers to the television networks that count on a slate of game broadcasts every fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine J. Wu
title: He Doesn’t Mind Being Shared, Unless His Mates Try to Eat Each Other’s Eggs
description: A Brazilian frog species engages in reproductive behavior never seen in amphibians before.
content: From the standpoint of sex, male frogs tend to segregate into two camps: the monogamous bunch and the free wheeling philanderers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kimberly Bradley
title: Berlin’s Art Scene: Are Reports of Its Death Exaggerated?
description: The news that three top collectors were leaving the city set off a string of negative headlines and prompted soul-searching from artists and administrators.
content: BERLIN — It’s not looking good for Berlin’s art scene, if you believe the newspaper headlines. This spring, Die Welt, a German daily, called the city an “art metropolis in decline.” The Financial Times said the art world had “said goodbye.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes and Mark Landler
title: Woody Johnson Asked State Dept. Auditors to Delete Claims of Offensive Remarks From Report
description: The American ambassador to Britain rejected accusations that he made racially or sexually inappropriate comments toward employees at the U.S. Embassy in London.
content: WASHINGTON — The American ambassador to Britain, Robert Wood Johnson IV, urged State Department investigators against publicly reporting allegations that he made sexually or racially inappropriate comments to embassy staff, according to a report released on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Doesn’t Trust Trump With the Nation’s Mail
description: The president said mail-in voting could put the election results in doubt. Seth Meyers joked that he sounded like “a loan shark saying, ‘I’d hate to see your thumbs get broken.’”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naomi Bardach
title: Kids Aren’t Big Covid-19 Spreaders. Really.
description: We’re so used to thinking of snotty-nosed kids as germ propagators. But that’s just not how Covid-19 works.
content: As a pediatrician, I love treating children, but I am well aware that the urgent care clinic where I work is not germ-free. Inevitably, I catch the occasional bug from a kid with a runny nose and a cough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: Ilhan Omar Wins House Primary in Minnesota
description: Ms. Omar, a member of the “Squad” of progressive women of color elected to the House two years ago, topped a well-funded challenger in a victory for the left.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — Representative Ilhan Omar of Minnesota fended off a well-funded primary challenger on Tuesday, ensuring a clean sweep of re-election fights for the group of first-term Democratic congresswomen of color known as the Squad and sending a message to Washington about the staying power of the party’s new progressive voices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Kamala Harris Crystallizes Trump’s View of Women: They’re ‘Nasty’ or Housewives
description: As Ms. Harris joined the Democratic ticket, the president wasted no time calling her “nasty” and praising the “suburban housewife” he says will vote for him. His views are out of step with reality.
content: WASHINGTON — In the hours since Senator Kamala Harris joined the Democratic presidential ticket, President Trump has responded by sorting women into two categories: the good “suburban housewife” he believes will vote for him, and nasty women who have not shown him or his political allies a sufficient amount of respect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: The Pleasures of Moth-Watching
description: It’s high moth season, and drawing you out into the dark is one of the many ways moths can enrich your life, if you let them.
content: Summer isn’t just butterfly season and tomato season, it’s also high moth season. And while you may think that a moth garden doesn’t sound quite as enchanting as a butterfly garden, I beg to differ. Thanks to guidance from some patient experts, these days you can call me the moth gardener.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What Happens When the Season Changes?
description: Taking refuge outdoors is still an option.
content: Welcome. It’s refreshing and awful at once, to read the questions and concerns of our audience here At Home, to discover how resilient and kind and optimistic we are, even as a sense of foreboding envelops some, bringing a kind of lethargic anxiety, an abiding loneliness, a worry about what happens when the season changes, when the air turns cold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Charlie Blackmon Could Set a Hitting Record. Would It Be Legitimate?
description: He doesn’t think so: “It’s not a full season; it’ll be an asterisk.” Even still, his .500 average so far is extraordinary on its own.
content: The plaque for Hugh Duffy at the Baseball Hall of Fame all but certifies his status as the premier single-season hitter in major league history. “He compiled a batting average in 1894 which was not to be challenged in his lifetime,” it states — and Duffy lived for six decades after his achievement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Thomas Kaplan
title: Trump’s push to cut payroll taxes has opened a Democratic line of attack.
description: When Mr. Trump announced that he was unilaterally deferring payroll taxes to bring economic relief to struggling Americans, he and his aides thought it would allow them to frame him as pro-worker.
content: When Mr. Trump announced that he was unilaterally deferring payroll taxes to bring economic relief to struggling Americans, he and his aides thought it would allow them to frame him as pro-worker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Kaplan and Katie Glueck
title: Here are four big tasks Biden and Harris face in their first appearance.
description: WILMINGTON, Del. — The Democratic ticket is finally complete. Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Kamala Harris, two Democrats from opposite coasts and different generations, are expected to make their first appearance as running mates in Wilmington around 4:30 p.m. Eastern time on Wednesday.
content: WILMINGTON, Del. — The Democratic ticket is finally complete. Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Kamala Harris, two Democrats from opposite coasts and different generations, are expected to make their first appearance as running mates in Wilmington around 4:30 p.m. Eastern time on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Marcus Payadue
title: Biden-Harris, Masks, Moths: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: The Small, Black-Owned Record Label That Made a Big Impact in 1970s D.C.
description: A new compilation of music released on Black Fire Records is a vital link between jazz and go-go, the city’s official genre.
content: In the mid-1970s, more often than not, the news coming from Washington was dreary. TV screens filled with images of the Watergate hearings, the war in Vietnam and an economy turning cold. But under the shadow of the Capitol, the city’s thriving Black community — making up three-fourths of its population — was in the midst of a renaissance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melanye Price
title: This Is Not Just a Victory for Kamala Harris
description: Millions of Black women and their political labor have made this historic moment possible.
content: It will be tempting for some to see Senator Kamala Harris of California’s place on the Democratic presidential ticket as a result of her race and gender, and to characterize it as an affirmative action selection. Others may see this moment as an isolated event rather than the result of the hard work of Black female candidates, political strategists and voters who have participated in the building of the Democratic Party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Carroll Hardy, Athlete With a Unique Distinction, Dies at 87
description: He was a college star in three sports and a successful N.F.L. executive. But he was better known as the only man who ever pinch-hit for Ted Williams.
content: Carroll Hardy, a reserve outfielder for the Boston Red Sox, was on the visitors’ bench in Baltimore late in the 1960 season when Ted Williams, the team’s megastar, fouled a pitch off his right foot during his first at-bat against the Orioles. Hobbled, he left the field.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: What the Harris Pick Means
description: Can a cautious V.P. choice jolt a campaign? Biden’s going to see. This is your morning tip sheet.
content: Bring on the hot takes, it’s finally over: Kamala Harris is Joe Biden’s running mate. It’s Wednesday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: James Harris, Towering Wrestler Known as Kamala, Dies at 70
description: He became a top draw portraying a stereotypical menacing African warrior who was always supposed to lose to his white opponents. He died of Covid-19.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Firshein
title: Help! I’m Abroad and My Visa Is About to Run Out
description: Many American citizens were traveling internationally when the pandemic struck. For those who have no interest in coming home in the short-term, but face expiring tourist visas, our columnist investigates the options.
content: I am an American citizen who arrived in Mexico in January on a Forma Migratoria Múltiple, the country’s standard 180-day visitor’s permit. My daughter lives there as a temporary resident, so I’d like to stay — and, besides, I really don’t want to fly back to the States during a global pandemic. Are you aware of any concessions or extensions for travelers who, for reasons relating to Covid-19, hunkered down abroad and now realize they have overstayed their welcome? Cisco
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brendan Porath
title: Masters Will Play Without Augusta’s Famed Roars
description: Augusta National Golf Club announced Wednesday that this year’s tournament will be played without patrons, making it the last of men’s golf majors to bar spectators.
content: The Augusta National Golf Club announced Wednesday that the 2020 Masters Tournament, postponed from its traditional April date to Nov. 12 to 15, will be held without patrons or guests in attendance. The decision was a response to the coronavirus pandemic and came after many other fixtures of the men’s professional golf schedule, including last week’s P.G.A. Championship, the first major championship of this unconventional year, previously were conducted without spectators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manisha Sinha
title: Why Kamala Harris Matters to Me
description: As an Indian-American professor of African-American history, I am experiencing Biden’s vice-presidential pick as a personal gift.
content: When I arrived in the United States in 1984, an Indian graduate student wanting to study African-American history, I was an anomaly. Most of my fellow South Asians were in STEM doctoral programs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin and Astead W. Herndon
title: The V.P. choice was both conventional and groundbreaking.
description: By choosing Ms. Harris as his running mate, Mr. Biden opted for a time-honored model in which running mates are not just governing partners but political understudies of sorts.
content: By choosing Ms. Harris as his running mate, Mr. Biden opted for a time-honored model in which running mates are not just governing partners but political understudies of sorts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: The Politics We Don’t See Matter as Much as Those We Do
description: Party strategists pay a lot of attention to redrawing district maps — and hope you won’t bother to think about it.
content: Some of the most important developments in politics do not happen every election cycle, but every ten years, when politicians scrap the old battleground map and struggle to replace it with a new one more favorable to their interests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Goudarzi
title: We All Speak a Language That Will Go Extinct
description: Even when we speak the same tongue, understanding and being understood can be a struggle. I would know.
content: “We can’t play tennis because you don’t have a net.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooke Jarvis
title: The Scramble to Pluck 24 Billion Cherries in Eight Weeks
description: Every single one needs to be picked by hand — even in a pandemic. Seasonal workers say they may be essential, but they feel disposable.
content: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: ‘Entitled’ Takes a Scalpel to What Men Feel They Automatically Deserve
description: The philosopher Kate Manne’s new book is about the ways in which male entitlement leads to a wide range of misogynistic behavior.
content: There’s a curious new refrain on the right — the repurposing of an old slogan from their opponents in the abortion fight to explain why people shouldn’t have to wear masks during a pandemic. “I thought it was my body, my choice!” the young Trump supporter Charlie Kirk recently declared on his podcast, a few days before an 80-year-old mentor of his died of complications from Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman and Nicole Perlroth
title: North Korean Hacking Group Attacks Israeli Defense Industry
description: Israel says the attack was thwarted, but a cybersecurity firm says it was successful. Some officials fear that classified data stolen by North Korea could be shared with Iran.
content: TEL AVIV — Israel claimed Wednesday that it had thwarted a cyberattack by a North Korea-linked hacking group on its classified defense industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: ‘No Slavery in Australia’? These Pacific Islanders Tell a Different Story
description: The Black Lives Matter movement has offered a rare moment for the descendants of plantation laborers brought aboard ships in the 19th century to make their family histories known.
content: MACKAY, Australia — Marion Healy’s great-grandfather Kwailu was just a boy when “recruiters” took him aboard a ship on a beach in the Solomon Islands. The destination was Australia, where, for meager wages, he would do backbreaking labor planting and cutting sugar cane for white farmers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: In One Corner, Trump. In the Other, Biden. Let the Debate Begin!
description: Presidential debates could use a serious overhaul.
content: With many usual fixtures of campaigning upended by the coronavirus pandemic — rallies, town halls, fund-raisers, conventions — President Trump has been looking to beef up one of the few remaining pieces: the debates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Leland
title: Carol Brock, Who Pushed at a ‘Pyrex Ceiling,’ Dies at 96
description: A veteran food writer, she founded Les Dames d’Escoffier, a society for women in the male-dominated culinary world.
content: Carol Brock, a food writer who helped women advance in the male-dominated culinary world by starting an organization called Les Dames d’Escoffier New York, died on July 27 in Manhasset, N.Y. She was 96.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: P.S.G. Breaks Its Glass Ceiling. Now Comes the Hardest Part.
description: Two late goals lifted the French champions past Atalanta and into the Champions League semifinals. Can their talent finally finish the job?
content: In that second half, the cavalry kept coming, wandering off the bench and onto the field one after the other. As Atalanta’s players blinked back the sweat, it must have felt as if Paris St.-Germain could draw from a bottomless well of talent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: I’m Type A Know-It-All. Leslie Knope Showed Me That’s a Good Thing
description: Amy Poehler’s character on “Parks and Recreation” is a vindication for principled, chatty ladies everywhere, even if her idealism feels impossible nowadays.
content: I didn’t like Leslie Knope at first. Then again, who did? Leslie, played by Amy Poehler, was the heroine of “Parks and Recreation,” a half-hour comedy on NBC that debuted in 2009 to aggressively middling reviews. Most write-ups shrugged it off as a mockumentary little sister to “The Office,” with which it shared a creative team. Even critics who liked it side-eyed Leslie. “Deluded” came up a lot when they described her. So did “ditsy.” The New York Times compared her to the “women who volunteer to look foolish on reality shows.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Pawel
title: California Had a Curse. Kamala Harris Just Broke It.
description: On her list of firsts: She will be the first Democrat from the Golden State to run on a major-party presidential ticket.
content: Kamala Harris has broken the California curse. In addition to her other historic firsts, she will be the first Democrat from the nation’s most populous state to run on a major-party presidential ticket.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Prasad Philbrick and Sanam Yar
title: The Biden-Harris Ticket
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: Joe Biden selected Senator Kamala Harris of California as his running mate on Tuesday. She is the first Black woman, and the first person of Indian descent, to be nominated for national office by a major party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariro Mzezewa and Kim Severson
title: Charleston Tourism Is Built on Southern Charm. Locals Say It’s Time to Change.
description: A powerful visitors’ bureau has pushed the South Carolina city to the top of “best” lists by selling gentility. Critics say that has come at the expense of history and the city’s Black population.
content: The week that George Floyd was killed by Minneapolis police officers, the Charleston, S.C., Convention & Visitors Bureau introduced a campaign to assure tourists that despite the coronavirus pandemic, Charleston — a city that has topped must-go travel lists for years — was ready to welcome them back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen and Taylor Lorenz
title: We Tested Instagram Reels, the TikTok Clone. What a Dud.
description: TikTok might not be winning over President Trump, but it sure beats its Instagram copycat for making and sharing short videos.
content: Millions of people have used the social media app TikTok to make and share short, fun, entertaining videos. I, Brian Chen, am not one of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Rosa
title: New York Tries to Keep Cool
description: A heat advisory is in effect until Wednesday night, and the high humidity poses a risk to vulnerable residents.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Progressives Killed Amazon’s Deal in New York. Is Industry City Next?
description: The fight over a rezoning plan in Brooklyn has pitted progressives and mainstream Democrats against each other.
content: A plan to bring tens of thousands of jobs to an overlooked corner of the city just outside Manhattan has become another battleground for New York City leaders. Progressives are attacking mainstream Democrats about their competing visions for the city. A powerful business is on the defensive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dorie Greenspan
title: The Particular Texture and Joy of Homemade Ice Cream
description: The moments spent watching and waiting for this chocolate-flake raspberry ice cream to form capture a childish delight that we could all use right now.
content: Because my husband, Michael, and I lived in the same neighborhood in Brooklyn before we met, we share memories that go back to our childhoods. We remember when there was a Woolworth’s on Avenue J — it was where I bought candy with my weekly allowance. We remember blackout cake from Ebinger’s and pizza from DiFara, now famous but then the local slice joint. So one recent night, when we were finishing dinner and Michael said, “I was thinking about the ice cream at that restaurant near Coney Island Avenue,” I jumped in and said, “Remember how it always had itsy bits of ice in it!” It was just the point he wanted to make. The ice was always there, but somehow still always unexpected. I liked it.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: After Virus Lockdowns, A Surge in Homicides Haunts Major Cities
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, August 12, 2020.
content: “We’re surrounded by murder, and it’s almost like your number is up.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Rosenberg, Astead W. Herndon and Nick Corasaniti
title: A QAnon supporter is (almost definitely) heading to Congress.
description: Conspiracy theorists won a major victory on Tuesday as Marjorie Taylor Greene, a Republican supporter of the convoluted pro-Trump movement QAnon, triumphed in her House primary runoff election in Georgia, all but ensuring that she will represent a deep-red district in Congress.
content: Conspiracy theorists won a major victory on Tuesday as Marjorie Taylor Greene, a Republican supporter of the convoluted pro-Trump movement QAnon, triumphed in her House primary runoff election in Georgia, all but ensuring that she will represent a deep-red district in Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Back to Sandwich City!
description: Fry up some shrimp and tuck it into a torpedo roll for a meal you’re not likely to soon forget.
content: Good morning. My friend Michael Gentile used to make these soft-shell crab sandwiches, the crabs fried in butter with a dusting of flour and Old Bay seasoning, on white bread with mayonnaise and really ripe summer tomatoes, and I got it into my head that I had to have one of those this August, preferably right away. But there were no peelers to be had at the fishmongers I visited, day after day. I was always 10 minutes too late. “We had them earlier,” said the man in the mask, inevitably, stomping his deck boots on the wet concrete floor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Administration Reaches Out to Democrats on Stimulus Bill
description: Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin talked with Speaker Nancy Pelosi for the first time since negotiations on a new coronavirus relief bill collapsed, but neither side showed any willingness to budge.
content: WASHINGTON — Steven Mnuchin, the Treasury secretary, spoke on Wednesday with Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California to discuss a coronavirus relief package, though the conversation appeared to do little to resolve the standoff between the White House and top congressional Democrats over another economic stimulus measure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Two Indianapolis Police Officers Charged With Assaulting Protesters
description: The two were indicted after videos taken by TV crews showed officers repeatedly striking one woman with batons and shoving another to the ground, the authorities said.
content: Two Indianapolis police officers have been charged with assaulting two women at a protest, the authorities said Wednesday, the latest officers to face criminal charges that they used excessive force against protesters demanding an end to police violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Kleeman
title: The Spiritual Power of Fat
description: Is it any surprise that when survival became a theme of daily life, I immediately thought of making cultured butter?
content: When the pandemic came to my city and I understood that I was about to be spending an enormous amount of time in my apartment, I thought of the German artist Joseph Beuys. The tedium of lockdown finds an analogue in his 1974 performance “I Like America and America Likes Me,” in which he shut himself in a SoHo art gallery for three days with a live coyote, some straw, dozens of copies of The Wall Street Journal and a heap of wool felt. Beuys understood that the animal imperative of survival is never far from our lives, even when that imperative is tidied and civilized almost beyond recognition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Delayed ‘Diana’ Musical to Be Streamed on Netflix
description: The show will be filmed in the empty Broadway theater where it had been playing in previews, and still plans to open in May 2021.
content: With Broadway still shuttered, Netflix is doing for the theater community what it and other streaming services have done for the movie business: airing content that can’t be seen where it was initially intended. On Wednesday, the Los Gatos-based company announced that it will stream a specially filmed version of “Diana: A Musical,” a new show about the British princess, ahead of its debut on Broadway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: The Dark Fairy Tale of Atalanta
description: This has been the most painful of years in Bergamo, a proud Italian city that became synonymous with the coronavirus. As it emerges from the pandemic, one bright spot has been its title-chasing soccer team.
content: BERGAMO, Italy — Giorgio Gori still smiles at the memory of that night. He was sitting with his son high in the stands, watching the unimaginable unfold. The party seemed to bubble up beneath them, gathering force until it consumed them, too. “Four goals? Against Valencia? At San Siro?” he said. He phrased them as questions, as if he just needed to check what he had seen was real.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tatiana Boncompagni
title: The New Nose: Is the Bump Back?
description: The cookie-cutter ski jump nose looks like a relic now, as cosmetic doctors approach rhinoplasties with a more artistic, individualized approach.
content: Twelve years ago, a young woman named Elina met with a number of plastic surgeons about her nose, which she described as having a pronounced bump and bulbous tip, traits she had inherited from her father. Each surgeon showed Elina, then 18 years old, an “after” rendition of herself that she described as jarring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Regrets? Even Brent Scowcroft Had a Few
description: In an oral history released after his death, the former national security adviser revealed a few key moments in which his ideas failed in the war against Saddam Hussein.
content: By the time he died last week at age 95, Brent Scowcroft had helped steer the nation through some of the most pivotal events of the modern era. As the much-admired national security adviser to two presidents, he became known as the archetype of a foreign policy steward, the model his successors vowed to emulate, though never as successfully.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Jeremy W. Peters
title: Her Voice? Her Name? G.O.P.’s Raw Personal Attacks on Kamala Harris
description: ‘Radical leftist’ or not progressive enough? In the hours after Ms. Harris’s announcement as Joe Biden’s vice president, the Trump campaign struggled to launch a clear attack on the Biden-Harris ticket.
content: WASHINGTON — Opening an ugly new chapter in the 2020 campaign, President Trump and allies in the Republican Party and on Fox News have swiftly gone all-in on sexist and personal attacks against Kamala Harris, the Democratic vice-presidential candidate, from Mr. Trump demeaning her as “angry” and “horrible” to commentators mocking her first name to comparing her to “payday lenders.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin and Astead W. Herndon
title: In Kamala Harris, a Choice at Once Safe and Energizing
description: Her selection as Joe Biden’s running mate was conventional by some political standards. But it was historic most of all, and especially sweet for many Black women.
content: WASHINGTON — In naming Kamala Harris as his running mate, Joseph R. Biden Jr. made a groundbreaking decision, picking a woman of color to be vice president and, possibly, a successor in the White House someday. Yet in some ways, Mr. Biden made a conventional choice: elevating a senator who brings generational and coastal balance to the Democratic ticket and shares his center-left politics at a time of progressive change in the party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Advisers Consider Whether Trump Can Cut Taxes Without Congress
description: Trump’s lawyers and economic advisers have studied how far they could stretch executive authority to set tax policy, though the legality of any cuts is dubious.
content: WASHINGTON — White House officials have explored whether President Trump has the power to sidestep Congress and unilaterally cut a broad swath of taxes as the president looks for ways to inject fuel into a slumping economy, according to a senior administration official.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Hess
title: The Fandom Around R.B.G. Is Out of Step With Reality
description: ‘The Notorious R.B.G.’ memes hit like relics as the symbol of progressive change looks more like a regular person for whom justice was not served.
content: When Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg revealed last month that she had been treated for cancerous lesions on her liver, a YouTube video whispered across the liberal internet like a prayer. The video, titled “Hang On Ruthie!” is a 2018 parody of the McCoys’ 1965 hit “Hang On Sloopy,” and every few months, it is resurrected through boomer chain emails and Facebook pages with names like the Rude Liberals. Filmed “somewhere in Oregon” by the musical duo Buffalo Romeo, “Hang On Ruthie!” features the earnestly progressive trappings of the Pacific Northwest (a local lesbian choir sings backup in black judicial robes) and a charmingly amateurish production (still photographs of Supreme Court justices are made to wink or bob their heads to the beat). The “Sloopy” lyrics are recast to celebrate Ginsburg’s legal prowess: “You know you argue so good/You know your briefs are so tight/You got the juris and the prudence/Keep counsel up all night.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: Ilhan Omar’s primary victory gives progressives another boost.
description: Representative Ilhan Omar of Minnesota fended off a well-funded primary challenger on Tuesday, ensuring a clean sweep of re-election fights for the group of first-term Democratic congresswomen of color known as the Squad and sending a message to Washington about the staying power of the party’s new progressive voices.
content: Representative Ilhan Omar of Minnesota fended off a well-funded primary challenger on Tuesday, ensuring a clean sweep of re-election fights for the group of first-term Democratic congresswomen of color known as the Squad and sending a message to Washington about the staying power of the party’s new progressive voices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer
title: The Nation Wanted to Eat Out Again. Everyone Has Paid the Price.
description: Governments and restaurant owners wanted to get back to business. But bars and restaurants have become a focal point for clusters of Covid infections.
content: Across the United States this summer, restaurants and bars, reeling from mandatory lockdowns and steep financial declines, opened their doors to customers, thousands of whom had been craving deep bowls of farro, frothy margaritas and juicy burgers smothered in glistening onions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Abi-Habib
title: Beirut’s Youngest Cancer Patients Lose Care Options After Blast
description: Many children undergoing chemotherapy in Lebanon now have nowhere to turn for treatment after an explosion destroyed hospitals and wiped out medicine stockpiles.
content: The children being treated at Beirut’s St. George Hospital built an extended family with each other, painting and dancing together when they had the energy and rubbing each other’s backs when they vomited after chemotherapy sessions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Brooke
title: Bike Shorts, It’s Your Time to Shine
description: Are stretchy shorts an enlightened choice for the times, or a tumble into sartorial laziness? Either way, they work.
content: Bike shorts were making their comeback as a fashion item well before “social distancing” entered our everyday vocabulary.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Historic V.P. Decision
description: Joe Biden’s vice-presidential search has ended: Kamala Harris will be his running mate. How did he settle on the California senator?
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Kamala Harris’s Cultural Impact
description: Biden’s pick for vice president comes with important advantages, but also some complexities.
content: Joe Biden’s selection of Kamala Harris, the daughter of a Jamaican father and a South Asian mother, both immigrants, is both historic and inspiring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $500,000 or Less
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: For the Crispiest Tofu, Leave It Alone
description: This simple recipe brings out its crunchy side, then pairs it with olives and blistered tomatoes.
content: One of the hardest techniques for an impatient person to master is frying tofu until it’s golden and very crisp.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Air Force Helicopter Hit by Gunfire Was Forced to Make Emergency Landing, F.B.I. Says
description: One crew member was treated at a hospital for injuries that were not life-threatening, according to the authorities, who said they were investigating the shooting.
content: The F.B.I. and the U.S. military said Wednesday they were investigating the shooting of an Air Force helicopter this week during a routine training exercise over Northern Virginia that injured one airman and forced the crew to make an emergency landing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: These Shows Are Made for Walking
description: The pandemic has darkened theaters around the country. So this summer, some are staging scenes in parks and fields for small groups of masked patrons.
content: ASHFIELD, Mass. — In trees. On stilts. Atop a roof. Aboard a boat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabriel Popkin
title: Global Warming Could Unlock Carbon From Tropical Soil
description: Warming soils in the tropics could cause microbes to release carbon dioxide from storage. One scientist called the finding “another example of why we need to worry more.”
content: Humble dirt could pack an unexpected climate punch, according to a new study published Wednesday in the journal Nature. An experiment that heated soil underneath a tropical rainforest to mimic temperatures expected in the coming decades found that hotter soils released 55 percent more planet-warming carbon dioxide than did nearby unwarmed areas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May and Austin Ramzy
title: ‘We Will Persevere’: A Newspaper Faces the Weight of Hong Kong’s Crackdown
description: Apple Daily, a pro-democracy paper known for celebrity gossip and hard-hitting investigations, has become a target in Beijing’s new national security law in Hong Kong.
content: HONG KONG — After more than 200 police officers raided the newsroom of Hong Kong’s biggest pro-democracy newspaper, Apple Daily, a staff reporter messaged the editor in chief with a question: Should I still go to work?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: As the economy sputters, Congress and White House remain deadlocked on more aid.
description: Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said on Wednesday that there had been no progress this week in negotiations with Congress over another economic stimulus package, and accused Democrats of being intransigent for political reasons.
content: Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said on Wednesday that there had been no progress this week in negotiations with Congress over another economic stimulus package, and accused Democrats of being intransigent for political reasons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
title: A Florida Sheriff Has Ordered His Deputies Not to Wear Masks
description: The sheriff forbade his deputies from wearing masks while on duty, with some exceptions, and also barred visitors to his offices from wearing them.
content: When the sheriff in Marion County, Fla, wrote an email to his deputies this week about a new mask order, he expected there would be complaints. “I can already hear the whining,” Sheriff Billy Woods wrote, noting that he did not make the decision “easily.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: Confidence in Police Is at Record Low, Gallup Survey Finds
description: For the first time in its 27 years of measuring attitudes toward the police, Gallup found that a majority of American adults do not trust law enforcement.
content: Amid waves of civil unrest as protesters across the country continue to demonstrate against police brutality, Americans’ confidence in the police has dropped to a record low, according to a Gallup poll released on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember and Astead W. Herndon
title: Progressives Didn’t Want Harris for V.P. They’re Backing Her Anyway.
description: Joe Biden’s selection of Kamala Harris reaffirmed progressives’ fears of a Biden administration rooted in establishment politics. But rather than revolt, many snuffed out their criticisms.
content: From the moment Bernie Sanders exited the presidential race in early April, many activists, organizers, progressive groups and elected officials had held out hope that Joseph R. Biden Jr. would elevate one of their ideological allies to the vice presidency — someone like Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts or Representative Karen Bass of California. Kamala Harris, an establishment-friendly senator from California and more of a moderate, was near the bottom of their list.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Hong
title: R. Kelly Allies Accused of Using Arson and Bribery to Silence Witness
description: Prosecutors say one defendant set fire to a car parked outside the house of a woman who had publicly accused the singer of abuse.
content: For more than a year, the singer R. Kelly has been awaiting trial on federal sexual abuse charges, facing the prospect of watching his accusers and former sexual partners testify against him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Kamala Harris, Russian vaccine, Belarus: Here’s what you need to know.
content: Former Vice President Joe Biden named Senator Kamala Harris of California on Tuesday as his running mate in the U.S. presidential election in November. She is the first Black woman and first person of Indian descent to be nominated for national office on a major party ticket.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 12, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Aug. 12, 2020.
content: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about the harsher impacts that the world’s poorest communities face with the rise in global temperatures misstated the findings of a study on heat in Athens since the late 1800s. The city experienced fewer than 20 hot days in total in the decade from 1897 until 1906, not fewer than 20 hot days per year. Similarly, there were fewer than 50 hot days in total from 1987-96, not per year; and more than 120 in total from 2007-16, not per year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Wong
title: Joshua Wong: Hong Kong Still Has Many Ways to Resist
description: We will respond to repression by demonstrating our solidarity creatively.
content: HONG KONG — Ever since a new round of pro-democracy protests broke out in Hong Kong last year, journalists from both local and global media have exposed how freedoms are shrinking, human rights are deteriorating and police brutality is worsening in the city.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Excited Again About a Woman on the Ticket
description: A former secretary of the Democratic National Committee recalls the first woman on a major-party ticket in 1984 and feels the same enthusiasm today. Also: Power outages; gaining weight.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: How Big a Role Will Kamala Harris Get to Play?
description: As Ms. Harris joins the Democratic ticket, the question now is how much power she will wield over the campaign and in office.
content: — Teresa Younger, president and chief executive of the nonprofit Ms. Foundation for Women
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Rosenberg, Astead W. Herndon and Nick Corasaniti
title: Marjorie Taylor Greene, a QAnon Supporter, Wins House Primary in Georgia
description: Ms. Greene’s victory came as six states were holding elections on Tuesday, with Ilhan Omar holding off a well-funded primary challenge in Minnesota.
content: Conspiracy theorists won a major victory on Tuesday as a Republican supporter of the convoluted pro-Trump movement QAnon triumphed in her House primary runoff election in Georgia, all but ensuring that she will represent a deep-red district in Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 11, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Aug. 11, 2020.
content: An article on Saturday about the re-election challenge faced by President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus misspelled the surname of one of his supporters. She is Lyudmila S. Krokhaleva, not Khrokhaleva.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: Britain’s New Record: A Recession Worse Than in Europe and North America
description: Seventeen years of economic growth have been wiped out in Britain’s late and long lockdown.
content: Britain discovered on Wednesday that its economy had suffered a recession deeper than any other reported by a European or North American country during the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu and Edmund Lee
title: It Was Business, It Was Personal: The Redstones’ Father-Daughter Feud
description: A period of estrangement between Shari Redstone and her combative father, Sumner Redstone, ended with a reconciliation before his death and the daughter taking over the family empire.
content: In more than 50 years as a force in the media industry, Sumner M. Redstone clashed with his only son, his nephew, his wife, his romantic partners, his business rivals and the actor Tom Cruise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siddhartha Mitter
title: Five Art Accounts to Follow on Instagram Now
description: Our critic looks in on a photographer in Los Angeles, a museum in Cape Town, fierce young critics in London and culture workers who are out there fighting for beauty and justice.
content: It’s August; an attempt at a fall culture season beckons, somehow, but a sense of great fragmentation persists. On Instagram I see artists and culture workers in Europe behaving more or less normally for the season — that is to say, on vacation. Elsewhere, new horrors have taken over — as in Beirut, where in the wake of a cataclysmic warehouse explosion, artists are sifting through the rubble of devastated gathering spaces and galleries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Prevost
title: House Hunting in London: Once a Dark Garage, Now an Airy Light Box
description: As Britain struggles to rid itself of the coronavirus, pent-up demand and a volatile market are spurring a frenzy of interest from home buyers.
content: This three-bedroom home, converted over the past two years from an auto mechanic’s garage, is just down the street from Mile End Park in East London. The modern design incorporates below-ground and staggered levels to maximize the house’s 1,600 square feet of living space, with a central glass atrium that runs from top to bottom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Health Experts Warn About Perils of New Virus Data Collection System
description: An administration shift is putting a burden on hospitals and undercutting the integrity of data on the pandemic, current and former members of a federal advisory panel said.
content: WASHINGTON — Nearly three dozen current and former members of a federal health advisory committee, including nine appointed or reappointed by the health secretary, Alex M. Azar II, are warning that the Trump administration’s new coronavirus database is placing an undue burden on hospitals and will have “serious consequences on data integrity.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: Top General in Middle East Says U.S. Troop Levels Will Drop in Iraq and Syria
description: The commander, Gen. Kenneth F. McKenzie Jr., said U.S. forces would continue to combat pockets of Islamic State fighters.
content: WASHINGTON — The top American military commander in the Middle East said on Wednesday that U.S. troop levels in Iraq and Syria would most likely shrink in the coming months, but that he had not yet received orders to begin withdrawing forces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Nick Corasaniti
title: Ohio State Football Is Canceled. Will Trump Take the Hit?
description: The Big Ten Conference’s decision to cancel its football season reverberated across Ohio, where the Buckeyes’ football program looms large. Some voters blamed President Trump’s handling of the virus.
content: CENTER OF THE WORLD, Ohio — As he stood outside the Dollar General store, loading groceries into his pickup, Dennis Kuchta pondered what it will mean not to have an Ohio State football season this fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Takenaga and Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: One Georgia district might foretell the chaos of the coming semester.
content: The first U.S. schools to resume in-person teaching have shown the perils of reopening with the virus still out of control, painting a picture of chaos and deeply divided communities. In one district in Georgia, nearly 1,200 students and staff members have already been ordered to quarantine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David A. Hopkins
title: What the Kamala Harris Pick Tells Us About Joe Biden
description: His choice is a characteristic example of his tendency to row in the direction of the day’s strongest political currents.
content: Joe Biden is often described as an ideological moderate. During the 2020 Democratic primary, political analysts routinely used the term to distinguish Mr. Biden from prominent rivals running to his left, especially the self-described socialist Senator Bernie Sanders and the “big structural change” advocate Senator Elizabeth Warren.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: QAnon Followers Are Hijacking the #SaveTheChildren Movement
description: Fans of the pro-Trump conspiracy theory are clogging anti-trafficking hotlines, infiltrating Facebook groups and raising false fears about child exploitation.
content: Recently, an acquaintance posted a photo on her Instagram story showing a map of the United States, filled with bright red dots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck and Thomas Kaplan
title: Biden and Harris Pledge a Strong Challenge to Trump and a Path Out of Crisis
description: Joe Biden and Kamala Harris made their debut as running mates in Wilmington, Del., offering a vision of recovery from the coronavirus and pressing their case that the president has made things worse at every turn.
content: WILMINGTON, Del. — Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Senator Kamala Harris made their debut as running mates in a high school gymnasium on Wednesday, pledging to lead the country out of the coronavirus crisis amid an onslaught of attacks from President Trump as the two national tickets went head-to-head for the first time, less than three months before Election Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: With the Biden-Harris Ticket, Environmental Justice Is a Focus
description: Climate change leaders said the choice of Harris signaled that Democrats will try to ensure that communities burdened by pollution would benefit from a transition to clean energy.
content: WASHINGTON — Just six days before Joseph R. Biden Jr. tapped Kamala Harris to be his running mate in the presidential election, the California senator released sweeping environmental justice legislation. The timing, climate activists said, was important if not prescient.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: The Digital V.P. Rollout
description: Announcing the selection of Kamala Harris, or any running mate, involves a lot more than just bunting and placards.
content: Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Covering the Housing Market at a Tipping Point
description: As experts fear a nationwide eviction crisis, a Times business reporter discusses the industry’s long-term problems and a nightmare in the making.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fahima Haque
title: Why One Activist Injured in Charlottesville Won’t Give Up
description: For Constance Paige Young, who was among the counterprotesters injured in Charlottesville, it is a moral obligation to continue showing up.
content: As Americans continue to protest systemic racism, showing up at rallies and demonstrations day after day in many cities across the country, the motivation for sustained activism is both personal and informed by one’s community. How do people keep going? What galvanizes them? For Constance Paige Young, who was among the counterprotesters injured in Charlottesville, Va., three years ago, after a white man drove his car into the crowd, killing one woman, it is a moral obligation to continue showing up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: G.O.P.ers Can’t Find Their Kamala
description: The attacks from Trump’s allies just don’t seem to fit.
content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: Who Could Replace Kamala Harris in the Senate?
description: Wednesday: Senator Kamala Harris is officially Joe Biden’s vice-presidential pick. Also: The Pac-12 won’t play football in the fall.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Cousin of an Apple Cobbler
description: Adesina O. Koiki makes his New York Times debut.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Far be it from me to spoil a puzzle, but it’s Wednesday and we need a midweek pick-me-up. So I have given the constructor Adesina O. Koiki — who makes his New York Times debut with this puzzle — permission to set this column on fire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac and Kate Conger
title: Google, Facebook and Others Broaden Group to Secure U.S. Election
description: More tech companies met with government agencies on Wednesday to fight disinformation on social media.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook, Google and other major tech companies said on Wednesday that they had added new partners and met with government agencies in their efforts to secure the November election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathleen Lynn
title: Montvale, N.J.: Friendly Neighbors, Good Schools and Low Taxes
description: Buyers drawn to the borough’s leafy neighborhoods and single-family homes also like the property taxes, which are less than they’d pay in nearby areas.
content: In Montvale, a Bergen County borough on the Rockland County border, the landscape is changing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Could the Beirut Explosion Be a Turning Point for Lebanon?
description: Chronic corruption must be rooted out.
content: The appalling negligence that left more than 2,700 tons of ammonium nitrate sitting for more than six years at Lebanon’s port in Beirut, just waiting to explode, perfectly if tragically encapsulates the official corruption and incompetence in a country where almost everything that can go wrong does go wrong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV Wednesday: Documentaries on Yusuf Hawkins and the Go-Go’s
description: “Yusuf Hawkins: Storm Over Brooklyn” debuts on HBO. And a film about the band the Go-Go’s airs on Showtime.
content: YUSUF HAWKINS: STORM OVER BROOKLYN (2020) 9 p.m. on HBO. Thirty-one years ago this month, Yusuf Hawkins was killed in the Bensonhurst neighborhood of Brooklyn, in what became one of the city’s most notorious hate crimes and a sign of its racial divisions in the 1980s and ’90s. This documentary revisits the case — in which Hawkins, a Black teenager, was pursued by a mob of white youths, then shot — through archival footage and interviews with Hawkins’s family. Also interviewed are public figures like the Rev. Al Sharpton, who led protests after the killing and helped turn the case into an argument for change. “I don’t know who shot Yusuf,” Sharpton said at Hawkins’s funeral in 1989, “but the system loaded the gun.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: Is Now the Time To Refinance Your Mortgage?
description: Rates on 30-year fixed mortgages have recently dipped below 3 percent, a 50-year low. Here’s how to go about refinancing your mortgage.
content: Rates on 30-year fixed mortgages have recently dipped below 3 percent, a 50-year low. Here’s how to go about refinancing your mortgage.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Hidden Gem in East London for $1.95 Million
description: This light-filled three-bedroom home in East London, converted over the past two years from an auto mechanic’s garage, is on the market.
content: This light-filled three-bedroom home in East London, converted over the past two years from an auto mechanic’s garage, is on the market.

title: What You Get for $950,000
description: An 1830s farmhouse in Cornwallville, a 19th-century house with a 1970s addition near Salt Lake City and a 1925 stone house in Haverford.
content: An 1830s farmhouse in Cornwallville, a 19th-century house with a 1970s addition near Salt Lake City and a 1925 stone house in Haverford.

title: The Night Garden and Its Inhabitants
description: It’s high moth season, and drawing you out into the dark is one of the many ways moth-watching can enrich your life.
content: It’s high moth season, and drawing you out into the dark is one of the many ways moth-watching can enrich your life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: ‘Are You OK?’: Audio Captures Father and Son in Beirut Hospital Minutes After Blast
description: An audio recording taken by Omar Abou Mrad at St. George Hospital in Beirut, Lebanon, where his son Yuri is a cancer patient, shows the sheer terror of the moment.
content: An audio recording taken by Omar Abou Mrad at St. George Hospital in Beirut, Lebanon, where his son Yuri is a cancer patient, shows the sheer terror of the moment.
